title: Self-Supervised Monocular Depth Estimation Robust to Reflective Surface Leveraged by Triplet Mining
author: Wonhyeok Choi (Daegu Gyeongbuk Institute of Science and Technology), Kyumin Hwang (Daegu Gyeongbuk Institute of Science and Technology), Wei Peng (Stanford University), Minwoo Choi (Daegu Gyeongbuk Institute of Science and Technology), Sunghoon Im (Daegu Gyeongbuk Institute of Science and Technology)
background: The paper focuses on enhancing depth estimation from single camera images in scenarios involving reflective surfaces, commonly found in real-world environments.
contribution: This paper introduces a reflection-aware triplet mining loss to solve the challenges posed by non-Lambertian surfaces, achieving more accurate depth predictions in complex scenes.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods struggle with reflective surfaces, often leading to incorrect depth estimations due to the violation of photometric constancy.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon existing methods by implementing a triplet mining strategy which discriminates between reflective and non-reflective regions to minimize errors effectively.

key_innovation: Utilizes a novel training strategy specifically designed to identify and manage reflective surfaces, significantly enhancing the robustness of depth estimation.
real_world_impact: The proposed approach can improve depth perception in applications such as autonomous navigation and augmented reality, where reflective surfaces are common challenges.
limitations: No explicit limitations are mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.monocular depth estimation: **Monocular depth estimation** refers to the process of predicting depth information from a single image without relying on stereo or multi-view setups.
new_terms.triplet mining: **Triplet mining** is a technique used to enhance learning by comparing three samples (anchor, positive, and negative) to better distinguish among them.
